review.title: Semi-Automatic Data Annotation, POS Tagging and Mildly Context-Sensitive Disambiguation: the eXtended Revised AraMorph (XRAM)
review.abstract: An extended, revised form of Tim Buckwalter's Arabic lexical and morphological resource AraMorph, eXtended Revised AraMorph (henceforth XRAM), is presented which addresses a number of weaknesses and inconsistencies of the original model by allowing a wider coverage of real-world Classical and contemporary (both formal and informal) Arabic texts. Building upon previous research, XRAM enhancements include (i) flag-selectable usage markers, (ii) probabilistic mildly context-sensitive POS tagging, filtering, disambiguation and ranking of alternative morphological analyses, (iii) semi-automatic increment of lexical coverage through extraction of lexical and morphological information from existing lexical resources. Testing of XRAM through a front-end Python module showed a remarkable success level.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: Tim Buckwalter's AraMorph (henceforth AM: see Buckwalter, 2002) is one of the most widely used electronic resources for the Arabic lexicon and morphology. Applications that use it include text analyzers, ontologies (e.g., the Arabic WordNet browser, see Fellbaum et al., 2006), data mining, and content extraction (e.g., ArMExLeR, Lancioni et al., 2013).However, the original version of AM exhibits a number of deficiencies that reduce the reach of the morphological analyzer and impede its applicability to a number of genres and text types. In particular, Buckwalter (2002) focused mainly on contemporary newspaper texts, whereby the analyst underestimates both lexical and morphological coverage - as well as structural selection (by erroneously increasing the amount of ambiguity because the inclusion of historically and linguistically implausible alternatives were taken by the RAM structure).

sections.heading: 2 Description of XRAM
sections.text: XRAM, just like AM and RAM, has a purpose to analyze text, but in a much more defined and thorough way. To improve the accuracy of the analysis, we have implemented a tool that is selectable by flag, adding a complementary field to the Buckwalter analyzer (see infra § 2.1). After selecting a single flag or set of flags, the text is tokenized according to the text genre and the entire punctuation and formatting structure is removed and factored. Therefore, the program creates a list of tokens that are ready to be processed by the XRAM analyzer, which aims to create a list of possible analyses for each token represented in the original text. Types (unique tokens) are analyzed, and a dictionary of analysis that assigns each type a POS and a lemma is created to reduce computing time.

sections.heading: 2.1 Flag-selectable usage markers
sections.text: To make XRAM linguistic analysis even more reliable, markers are provided for graphical, morphological, and lexical characteristics that belong to specific language variants, such as classical Arabic (CA), modern standard Arabic (MSA, formal), and informal colloquial Arabic (ICA, informal), and technical and scientific sub-languages. Buckwalter & Parkinson's (2011) Frequency Dictionary (Buckwalter and Parkinson, 2011) provides morphological, syntactic, orthographic, and phonetic information for each recorded problem, as well as usage restrictions and register variations, depending on the corpus in which problem can be found, exclusively or most frequently. Markers are encoded with flags that can be selected according to the language diversity or genre the corpus is to be processed.

sections.heading: 2.2 Probabilistic mildly context-sensitive annotation
sections.text: POS labeling is one of the core tasks AM has performed since its inception, along with tokenization and word segmentation. sections.heading: 2.3 Lexical and morphological XML tagging of texts
2.4 Semi-automatic increment of lexical coverage
sections.text: One of the weaknesses of AraMorph is the limited range of text genres on which the resource is based: the lexical files and the compatibility tables included in the program are largely based on newspaper texts and other non-literary texts, which largely comprise the LDC Arabic corpus. Not only is the program unbalanced and representative of a limited part of the Arabic vocabulary, but its reference works are based on the lack of any stylistic and chronological information, as well as on various problems that may arise from the analysis of other textual genres, especially at the contemporary and informal levels.

sections.heading: 3 Validation and research grounds
sections.text: The evaluation of a tool such as XRAM differs primarily in that the system purposely outputs all available analyses and does not provide analysis (e.g. a thorough preliminary reconstruction or error correction) where the analyzer has not found any. A first evaluation parameter is the rate of undetected words depending on the genre of text (see Table 1 above): While the performance of XRAM in MSA texts is slightly better than that of AM, more specific genres exhibit remarkably higher performance due to usage markers and greater lexicon coverage.

sections.heading: 4 Conclusion
sections.text: XRAM significantly improves the performance of AM texts, especially for genre-specific texts. It can be further improved by extending the filtering and ranking modules and increasing the lexicon's reach, while minimizing ambiguity through an increasingly sophisticated usage mark mapping. Another development is the integration of current research into formal grammar (in particular Combinatory Categorial Grammar, CCG: Steedman, 1996) into the ranking module.

However, the original version of AM shows a number of shortcomings which reduce the coverage of the morphological analyzer and hinder its applicability to a number of genres and text types. Some of these inconsistencies were tackled by the Revised AM model (henceforth RAM) presented in Boella et al. (2011). In order to enhance the accuracy of the analysis we implemented a flag-selectable usage markers tool through the addition of a supplementary field in the Buckwalter analyzer (cfr infra § 2.1). After selecting a single flag or a set of flags, according to the text genre, the text is tokenized and all the punctuation and formatting structure is stripped and factored out. Hence, the program produces a list of tokens ready to be processed by the XRAM analyzer, which aims to create a list of possible analyses for each token represented in the original text. Types (distinct tokens) are analyzed and a dictionary of analysis, that assigns to each type a POS and a lemma, is created in order to reduce computing time. As mentioned above, ambiguity is a significant weakness in the original AM model, which definitely compromises the correct analysis of the text. The XRAM RE module intervenes to reduce this ambiguity by filtering candidate analyses through a limited set of regular expressions. This module introduces a limited amount of context-sensitiveness in the system. Analyses that survive the RE module are then ranked through a simple Language Model (LM) module, based upon Buckwalter and Parkinson’s (2011) frequency list.

The LM component uses a hybrid approach: a order-3 language model drawn from a manually corrected sample is compounded with frequencies for individual POS-lemma tuples drawn from Buckwalter & Parkinson (2011). This will drastically change the previous versions of AM, giving the research in the field of Arabic Corpus Linguistics and Arabic Computational Linguistics a whole new perspective and a even more functional degree of analysis, creating a morphologic-syntax interface.
